episodeTitleJapanese: まさかの再上陸！ルフィ海軍本部（マリンフォード）へ！
episodeTitleRomanized: Masaka no Saijōriku! Rufi Marinfōdo e!
description: Luffy, Jinbe, and Rayleigh make an unexpected return to Marineford. After circling the island in a stolen Marine ship, Luffy enters the plaza alone, rings the Ox Bell sixteen times, and drops flowers into the largest battle crater to pay respects to the fallen. This ceremonial act carries a hidden message for his scattered crew members while the world interprets it as a declaration of a new era. Meanwhile, Sengoku steps down and nominates Aokiji as his successor, Koby awakens Observation Haki, and various pirate crews react to Luffy's bold statement as they enter the New World.

openingSong.title: Fight Together
openingSong.titleJapanese: ファイト・トゥゲザー

events.title: Marine Intelligence Briefing on Marineford Aftermath
events.description: Lieutenant Commander Brannew conducts a briefing about the aftermath of the Marineford War, revealing that Luffy survived and discussing the implications. The room of vice-admirals discusses how the war has shifted the balance of power in the world.
events.significance: Establishes the global impact of the Marineford War and sets up Luffy's return as a significant event that the Marines are monitoring closely.

events.title: Luffy Returns to Marineford with Rayleigh and Jinbe
events.description: A stolen Marine ship approaches Marineford carrying three figures: Monkey D. Luffy, Silvers Rayleigh, and Jinbe. They circle the destroyed fortress island while Marines scramble to respond to this unexpected intrusion.
events.significance: Marks Luffy's bold return to the site of his greatest trauma and defeat, demonstrating his resilience and setting up his message to his crew. The presence of Rayleigh signals to the world that Luffy may be groomed as Roger's successor.

events.title: Luffy Rings the Ox Bell 16 Times
events.description: Luffy enters the Marineford plaza alone and rings the sacred Ox Bell sixteen times. Traditionally, the bell is rung eight times to thank the old year and eight times to welcome the new year, but sixteen consecutive rings signals a momentous event - the end of one era and the beginning of another. Photographers capture the moment, which will be broadcast worldwide.
events.significance: This iconic moment serves multiple purposes: publicly, it appears as Luffy declaring the dawn of a new era; secretly, it's part of Rayleigh's plan to send a coded message to the Straw Hat crew about changing their reunion plans. The symbolism of ringing the bell at the site of Ace's death also represents Luffy's way of honoring his fallen brother and all who died in the war.

quotes.text: The end of one era and the beginning of another!
quotes.speaker: Killer
quotes.context: Killer interpreting the meaning of the 16 bell rings

events.title: Luffy Pays Respects with Flowers
events.description: After ringing the bell, Luffy walks to the largest crater created during the battle and drops a bouquet of flowers into it, holding his straw hat to his chest in a gesture of respect and mourning for those who fell in the war, particularly Ace and Whitebeard.
events.significance: A poignant moment showing Luffy's emotional growth and respect for the fallen warriors. This act of remembrance demonstrates that despite his cheerful nature, Luffy deeply honors those who sacrificed themselves.

events.title: The Hidden 3D2Y Message
events.description: Photographs of Luffy at Marineford capture him with a temporary tattoo on his arm reading '3D2Y' with the '3D' crossed out. While the Marines and most of the world interpret his actions as a declaration of war, this is actually a coded message to his crew: instead of meeting in 3 days as originally planned, they should reunite in 2 years after training.
events.significance: This clever message, orchestrated by Rayleigh, changes the entire trajectory of the Straw Hat Pirates' journey. It sets up the two-year timeskip and demonstrates Luffy's (and Rayleigh's) strategic thinking. Only the Straw Hats understand the true meaning, showing their deep bond.

quotes.text: Luffy doesn't do sneaky, clever stuff like that! This must be Rayleigh's plan.
quotes.speaker: Roronoa Zoro
quotes.context: Zoro recognizing that the coded message was Rayleigh's idea

events.title: Sengoku Nominates Aokiji as Fleet Admiral
events.description: Fleet Admiral Sengoku officially steps down from his position and nominates Admiral Aokiji (Kuzan) as his successor to lead the Marines. This recommendation sets the stage for major changes in Marine leadership.
events.significance: Begins the transition of Marine leadership following the Marineford War. Sengoku's choice of Aokiji over Akainu reflects his preference for a more moderate approach to justice, though this decision will later be contested by the World Government.

events.title: Koby's Observation Haki Awakening
events.description: It is revealed that Koby awakened Observation Haki (Kenbunshoku Haki) during the chaos of the Marineford War. The trauma and intensity of the battlefield triggered this latent ability, allowing him to sense the emotions and presence of others.
events.significance: Marks a major milestone in Koby's growth as a Marine. His Haki awakening during the war demonstrates his potential and foreshadows his future as a powerful Marine officer. This also shows that extreme situations can trigger Haki awakening.

events.title: Smoker Requests Transfer to G-5
events.description: Vice Admiral Smoker formally requests a transfer to the G-5 Marine base in the New World, one of the most dangerous and lawless Marine branches. His request is motivated by his desire to continue pursuing pirates in the most challenging waters.
events.significance: Sets up Smoker's future role in the New World and his eventual confrontation with the Straw Hats on Punk Hazard. The G-5 base is known for housing rough, unorthodox Marines, which suits Smoker's independent style.

events.title: Eustass Kid Pirates in the New World
events.description: Eustass Kid and his crew are shown having already entered the New World. They read about Luffy's return to Marineford in the newspaper and discuss its implications. Kid remarks that the New World makes the first half of the Grand Line look like paradise by comparison.
events.significance: Establishes that the Supernovas have scattered and are beginning their New World journeys. Kid's reaction to Luffy's actions shows the competitive dynamic between the Worst Generation captains.

quotes.text: The first half of the Grand Line was paradise compared to the New World.
quotes.speaker: Eustass Kid
quotes.context: Commenting on the harsh realities of the New World

events.title: Capone Bege Encounters Sea Monster
events.description: Capone Bege and his Fire Tank Pirates sail through the New World. Despite reading about Luffy's actions, Bege remains confident, stating that whoever makes the final move will be the victor. Shortly after, their ship is suddenly lifted into the air by a massive sea creature.
events.significance: Demonstrates the unpredictable and dangerous nature of the New World where even confident pirates like Bege can be caught off guard. Shows the Supernovas facing the harsh reality of these waters.

quotes.text: Whoever makes the final move will ultimately be the victor.
quotes.speaker: Capone Bege

events.title: Brownbeard's First Appearance
events.description: On the island of Foodvalten, a pirate captain named Brownbeard confronts Basil Hawkins, claiming the island as his territory and demanding that Hawkins leave. Brownbeard appears as a large man with a brown beard.
events.significance: Introduces Brownbeard, who will later become relevant in the Punk Hazard arc. This encounter establishes the territorial conflicts occurring in the New World.

events.title: Hawkins Confronts Brownbeard
events.description: Basil Hawkins responds to Brownbeard's territorial claim by reading his tarot cards and coldly stating that he doesn't like jokes and can see the shadow of death over Brownbeard. Hawkins then activates his Devil Fruit power, preparing to eliminate Brownbeard.
events.significance: Demonstrates Hawkins' abilities and ruthless nature. Shows that the New World is a place where territorial disputes are settled violently and established pirates can be quickly defeated by the new generation.

quotes.text: I don't like jokes. I can see the shadow of death over you.
quotes.speaker: Basil Hawkins

events.title: Urouge at Raijin Island
events.description: The Mad Monk Urouge and his crew attempt to land on Raijin Island, which is being constantly struck by lightning bolts. An elderly woman in a small boat approaches them, asking if they would like to buy an umbrella. Urouge's crew struggles with the dangerous weather conditions.
events.significance: Showcases another unique and dangerous island in the New World, emphasizing the extreme environmental hazards pirates must navigate. The mysterious old woman hints at residents who have adapted to these conditions.

quotes.text: The end of one era and the beginning of another!
quotes.speaker: Killer
quotes.context: Interpreting Luffy's ringing of the Ox Bell 16 times

quotes.text: Luffy doesn't do sneaky, clever stuff like that! This must be Rayleigh's plan.
quotes.speaker: Roronoa Zoro
quotes.context: Recognizing the coded message in Luffy's actions

quotes.text: The first half of the Grand Line was paradise compared to the New World.
quotes.speaker: Eustass Kid
quotes.context: Commenting on the dangers of the New World

quotes.text: Whoever makes the final move will ultimately be the victor.
quotes.speaker: Capone Bege

quotes.text: I don't like jokes. I can see the shadow of death over you.
quotes.speaker: Basil Hawkins

themes.description: The episode centers on the concept of endings and new beginnings - Luffy's symbolic declaration of a new era, Sengoku's retirement, and the Straw Hats preparing to reunite stronger after two years. The 16 rings of the Ox Bell represent closing one chapter and opening another.
themes.symbolism: The Ox Bell's 16 rings serve as the central symbol - traditionally used for New Year's ceremonies, here it marks the transition from one era to another. The flowers dropped in the crater symbolize both mourning the past and honoring those who made the future possible.
culturalReferences: The Ox Bell ceremony parallels Japanese New Year traditions of temple bell ringing (Joya no Kane), where bells are rung 108 times to cleanse Buddhist sins

themes.description: Rayleigh's clever plan to send a hidden message through a public spectacle demonstrates the deep trust and understanding between Luffy and his crew. While the world sees a declaration of war, the Straw Hats immediately understand the true meaning.
themes.symbolism: The 3D2Y tattoo represents the bond between crew members - a shared language that outsiders cannot comprehend. It shows that true nakama can communicate beyond words.

themes.description: Luffy's return to Marineford to pay respects shows his growth in processing grief and trauma. Rather than avoiding the painful site of Ace's death, he confronts it directly with a gesture of remembrance.
themes.symbolism: The flowers and the moment of silence represent acceptance and moving forward while never forgetting those who were lost.

themes.theme: The Harsh Reality of the New World
themes.description: The episode contrasts Luffy's symbolic actions with the brutal reality facing the Supernovas in the New World. Every crew shown encounters immediate danger, emphasizing that the second half of the Grand Line requires more than ambition.
themes.symbolism: The various environmental hazards (lightning, sea monsters) represent the New World as a proving ground that will separate the strong from the weak.

characterSpotlights.development: Luffy shows emotional maturity by returning to the traumatic site of Ace's death to pay proper respects. He participates in Rayleigh's clever plan, demonstrating growth in strategic thinking even while maintaining his straightforward nature.
keyActions: Returns to Marineford with Rayleigh and Jinbe
Rings the Ox Bell sixteen times
Drops flowers in the battle crater

characterSpotlights.development: Rayleigh demonstrates his wisdom and strategic brilliance by orchestrating a plan that serves multiple purposes - allowing Luffy to mourn, sending a coded message to the crew, and making a statement to the world.
Sengoku steps down from his position, showing the toll the war has taken. His nomination of Aokiji reveals his preference for a more moderate form of justice over Akainu's absolutism.

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime expands on the Supernova scenes in the New World, showing more details of their encounters and the environmental dangers they face.
Additional Marine reaction scenes and dialogue were added to emphasize the global impact of Luffy's actions.

trivia.fact: This episode marks one of the last appearances of Sengoku voiced by Takkō Ishimori before his death from bladder cancer in January 2013.
The opening 'Fight Together' by Namie Amuro was specifically created for the Post-War Arc and was the last opening of the first half of One Piece before the timeskip.
The episode adapts Chapter 594 titled 'Message', which was released on August 2, 2010, exactly one year and 19 days before the episode aired.
Pandaman appears in one of the newspaper photographs of Luffy at Marineford, maintaining the series tradition of hidden cameos.
The 16 bell rings symbolize the transition between eras, mirroring how Japanese Buddhist temples ring bells 108 times on New Year's Eve to cleanse worldly desires.
